linkTarget.anchoringText: The field is located in the North of Oman. It is a shallow 20Km long elongated carbonate monocline with an eroded fault escarpment and a hydrocarbon column of more than 400 m. This carbonate reservoir consists of seven sub-units of cretaceous age which are separated by extensive shale layers (see Fig.1), yet in dynamic interaction via faults and fractures.

image-wrap.label: Figure 1
image-wrap.caption: Cross-section showing the well placement at different stratigraphic layers to date; note the varying strategies per layer.

formatted-caption.caption-text: Cross-section showing the well placement at different stratigraphic layers to date; note the varying strategies per layer.

linkTarget.anchoringText: Recognising the interplay of these factors, we are introducing the concept of shallow GOGD “floor wells” to optimise secondary oil rims development and accelerate recovery (see fig.2).

image-wrap.label: Figure 2
image-wrap.caption: Interpretation of parallel macro and meso GOGD processes taking place simultaneously but at different pace in the structure. Left) Oil rim gets generated in the major fault/fracture corridor network, whilst layer constrained GOGD process in the background fractures develop secondary oil rims shallower in the structure. Right) Faults act as conduits for pressure and fluids but isolate parallel processes within the individual layers bounded vertically by shales and laterally by faults. Note secondary oil rim development depends on layer thickness and block dimensions.

formatted-caption.caption-text: Interpretation of parallel macro and meso GOGD processes taking place simultaneously but at different pace in the structure. Left) Oil rim gets generated in the major fault/fracture corridor network, whilst layer constrained GOGD process in the background fractures develop secondary oil rims shallower in the structure. Right) Faults act as conduits for pressure and fluids but isolate parallel processes within the individual layers bounded vertically by shales and laterally by faults. Note secondary oil rim development depends on layer thickness and block dimensions.

figure-specific-caption.caption-text: Oil rim gets generated in the major fault/fracture corridor network, whilst layer constrained GOGD process in the background fractures develop secondary oil rims shallower in the structure.

Faults act as conduits for pressure and fluids but isolate parallel processes within the individual layers bounded vertically by shales and laterally by faults. Note secondary oil rim development depends on layer thickness and block dimensions.

linkTarget.anchoringText: The field is a long monocline located in the tilted footwall of a partly-inverted NW-SE regional-scale normal fault. The general structure of the field has evolved during two major stages of deformation: Late Cretaceous (Alpine I) and Miocene (Alpine II). Structural features at all scales systematically belong to two main directional sets oriented respectively along WNW and NW strike directions. These two main sets of fracture orientation reflect the imprint at reservoir scale of the well-calibrated regional structural history2,3 (see fig.3).

image-wrap.label: Figure 3
image-wrap.caption: Structural history of the field (modified from Al Kindi and Richard1’ 2’ 3’). (1) Campanian to Maestrichtian transtension (Alpine I): development of the main NW-SE normal fault with several hundreds of meters throw. and a dense set of smaller faults and fracture corridors oriented NW-SE and NNW-SSE as part of its damage zone. (2) Miocene transpression (Alpine II): during Zagros collision, the main fault is partly inverted and the Tertiary units are detached and folded above the Fiqa shales, creating the surface topography. Cretaceous and underlying units are intensely deformed by a set of NE-SW and NNE-SSW faults and fracture corridors.

formatted-caption.caption-text: Structural history of the field (modified from Al Kindi and Richard1’ 2’ 3’). (1) Campanian to Maestrichtian transtension (Alpine I): development of the main NW-SE normal fault with several hundreds of meters throw. and a dense set of smaller faults and fracture corridors oriented NW-SE and NNW-SSE as part of its damage zone. (2) Miocene transpression (Alpine II): during Zagros collision, the main fault is partly inverted and the Tertiary units are detached and folded above the Fiqa shales, creating the surface topography. Cretaceous and underlying units are intensely deformed by a set of NE-SW and NNE-SSW faults and fracture corridors.

figure-specific-caption.caption-text: Campanian to Maestrichtian transtension (Alpine I): development of the main NW-SE normal fault with several hundreds of meters throw. and a dense set of smaller faults and fracture corridors oriented NW-SE and NNW-SSE as part of its damage zone.

Miocene transpression (Alpine II): during Zagros collision, the main fault is partly inverted and the Tertiary units are detached and folded above the Fiqa shales, creating the surface topography. Cretaceous and underlying units are intensely deformed by a set of NE-SW and NNE-SSW faults and fracture corridors.

linkTarget.bib: 1’ M. Al-Hadhrami, M. Boya Ferrero, R. Kawar, E. Unal, A. Wahaibi, L. Bazalgette, S. Al-Farsi, K. Khabouri. A Giant Reservoir is Talking and we are Listening: characterisation and Understanding of a Giant Fractured Reservoir in Oman with Extensive Years of Production
2’ M. Al-Kindi, P. Richard, “The main structural stypes of the hydrocarbon reservoirs in Oman”, 2014, Geological society, London, Special Publications, v.392 p 4009–445. Doi:10.1144/SP392.20

3’ J. Filbrand, S. al-Dhahab, A. Al0-Habsy, K. Harris, J. Keating, S. Al-Mahruqi, S. Ozkata, P. Richard, T. Robertson, 2006, “Kinematics interpretation and structural evolution of North Oman, block 6, since the late Cretacesous and implications for timing of hydrocarbon migrations inot Cretaceous reservoirs”. Geoarabia v.11, no1, p.97-140

linkTarget.anchoringText: Three main scales of structural features (see fig. 4) are identified using the integration of available multi-source datasets1:

image-wrap.label: Figure 4
image-wrap.caption: Sketch illustrating the concept of faults & fracture corridors (in red) and background fractures (in grey) with respect to the presence of shales at the bottom of the depositional cycles.

formatted-caption.caption-text: Sketch illustrating the concept of faults & fracture corridors (in red) and background fractures (in grey) with respect to the presence of shales at the bottom of the depositional cycles.

linkTarget.anchoringText: Fault and fracture corridors maps and 3D models, including different realizations related to confidence level (see fig.5); critical for infill well location choices.

image-wrap.label: Figure 5
image-wrap.caption: Faults & fracture corridors (in red) scenarios: Left) Low case map, Mid) Reference case map, Right) High case map

formatted-caption.caption-text: Faults & fracture corridors (in red) scenarios: Left) Low case map, Mid) Reference case map, Right) High case map

linkTarget.anchoringText: This is a very shallow giant oil field. The hydrocarbons storage resides within the porous matrix (see fig.6) despite the overwhelming imprint of fractures on fluid transport and performance described in the previous chapter. Facies and reservoir quality are fairly variable throughout the stratigraphy; microporous bioturbated carbonate facies (high porosity and low permeability) are dominant, in particular in our units of interest.

image-wrap.label: Figure 6
image-wrap.caption: Type Log. The current study has focused on the C & D intermediate layers with net sand body thickness of 40m and 18 m respectively.

formatted-caption.caption-text: Type Log. The current study has focused on the C & D intermediate layers with net sand body thickness of 40m and 18 m respectively.

linkTarget.anchoringText: Bioturbation textures: the dominant microporous wackstones/packestones facies are intensively bioturbated, with the exception of the presence of rudist rich leached facies at the top of the sequences; this result in “nodular textures” (see fig.7) which exacerbate the appearance of vertical heterogeneity of the unit based on small scale measurements (such as core plugs); overall, it is important to realise that the units are homogeneously bioturbated which has consequences for poor efficiency of water flood and relative permeability considerations previously reported by Abu-Shiekah5

image-wrap.label: Figure 7
image-wrap.caption: Core images illustrating depositional facies (C & D layers). Bioturbated Ramp facies (mid photograph) constitute the majority of the D & C units. Rudist rich facies Bioturbated Ramp facies Clay rick Ramp facies & shale

formatted-caption.caption-text: Core images illustrating depositional facies (C & D layers). Bioturbated Ramp facies (mid photograph) constitute the majority of the D & C units. Rudist rich facies Bioturbated Ramp facies Clay rick Ramp facies & shale

linkTarget.anchoringText: The main control on porosity and permeability is now understood to be the water depth at the time of deposition influencing the initial fabrics and their diagenetic overprint: deposition at deeper water depth (at the bottom of the sequences) results on muddier facies that through dissolution transform into higher porosity despite lower permeability (see Fig. 8-right). The minor contrast but consistent stacking of rock quality has consequences for development, since we have observed1 a preferential de-saturation of marginally less porous intervals at the top of the sequences (apparently defying gravity but consistent with core data and log resistivity post injection).

image-wrap.label: Figure 8
image-wrap.caption: Sketch illustrating the concept of cyclicity of reservoir quality. Blue is used to represent marginally higher permeability RRT with respect to green being lower permeability; shales are black. (Left) Distribution of permeability based on poroperm modeling workflows; (right) geological concept of depositional water depth and diagenesis overprint resulting in slight improvement of permeability of the shallower bioturbated facies (independent of porosity).

formatted-caption.caption-text: Sketch illustrating the concept of cyclicity of reservoir quality. Blue is used to represent marginally higher permeability RRT with respect to green being lower permeability; shales are black. (Left) Distribution of permeability based on poroperm modeling workflows; (right) geological concept of depositional water depth and diagenesis overprint resulting in slight improvement of permeability of the shallower bioturbated facies (independent of porosity).

figure-specific-caption.caption-text: Distribution of permeability based on poroperm modeling workflows
geological concept of depositional water depth and diagenesis overprint resulting in slight improvement of permeability of the shallower bioturbated facies (independent of porosity)

linkTarget.anchoringText: The initial oil distribution in this field, before development started is characterised by the presence of tilted contacts as defined from early well data (see fig.9). We have interpreted1 such contact as a clear imprint on saturation of the most recent tectonic rotation of the structure (AlpineII) after the charge of the field with hydrocarbons. The workflow leading to the interpretation of the pre-production fluid fill cycle has been reported in a previous publication4.

image-wrap.label: Figure 9
image-wrap.caption: Map of the field where the initial contacts are predicted4 from ground floor elevation as a proxy for paleo-depth; tectonic rotation of the structure tilted the contacts post charge. Note the contacts are colour coded according to stratigraphic unit (A, C, D, and E). Note quality/stratigraphic variability is around 10 m whilst geographical variability is up to 40 m (10 m per depth subdivision on y axis)

formatted-caption.caption-text: Map of the field where the initial contacts are predicted4 from ground floor elevation as a proxy for paleo-depth; tectonic rotation of the structure tilted the contacts post charge. Note the contacts are colour coded according to stratigraphic unit (A, C, D, and E). Note quality/stratigraphic variability is around 10 m whilst geographical variability is up to 40 m (10 m per depth subdivision on y axis)

linkTarget.anchoringText: Observations of variable GOC are in alignment with the description by Boerrigeter7 of behavior of GOGD process in the presence of capillary discontinuities (see Fig 10- graphics d & e).

image-wrap.label: Figure 10
image-wrap.caption: After Boerrigter7 SPE110403. GOGD in the presence of flow barriers/capillary discontinuities.

formatted-caption.caption-text: After Boerrigter7 SPE110403. GOGD in the presence of flow barriers/capillary discontinuities.

linkTarget.bib: 7 Nicholls, C. A., Boom, W., Geel, J., Al Khodori, S., and Al Lawati, M. 1999. “Fracture Modeling as a Key to Waterflood Development of the Fahud Field Natih-E Reservoir”. SPE conference paper presented at the Middle East Oil Show and Conference, Bahrain. http://dx.doi.org/10.2118/53211-MS.

linkTarget.anchoringText: There is evidence for a deep oil rim development in the main fracture network in this field which is produced through long horizontal high rate wells at the bottom of the structure. On the other hand, there is also log confirmation of pockets of gas in the matrix at different depths even within the same stratigraphy and within geographical proximity (see fig.11 where 100m delta gas contact in matrix was logged in the 90s). There is not a single GOC in the matrix for the field or even for a specific stratigraphic layer.

image-wrap.label: Figure 11
image-wrap.caption: Example of gas-oil de-saturation through Pulsed Neutron Logs in observation wells. Left) Well-146 GOC@220mTVDSS in 1999. Right) Well-29 GOC @310mTVDSS in 1996. Note the contact has moved to deeper depth in C2 in the sector 2 well, than the observed shallower contact (100 m shallower) in the sector 1 well, despite proximity of the wells and pressure communication. Left) Example of Gradio Surveys in observation wells in C layer. Note different depth of contacts and geographical location in the map.

formatted-caption.caption-text: Example of gas-oil de-saturation through Pulsed Neutron Logs in observation wells. Left) Well-146 GOC@220mTVDSS in 1999. Right) Well-29 GOC @310mTVDSS in 1996. Note the contact has moved to deeper depth in C2 in the sector 2 well, than the observed shallower contact (100 m shallower) in the sector 1 well, despite proximity of the wells and pressure communication. Left) Example of Gradio Surveys in observation wells in C layer. Note different depth of contacts and geographical location in the map.

linkTarget.anchoringText: The interpretation of the gravity processes in our field is supported by dynamic data on performance of shallow wells, where individual well gas production is not related to the placement depth (see Fig. 12).

image-wrap.label: Figure 12
image-wrap.caption: Performance of wells drilled at different depths. Wells are colour coded by depth. Note best producers in green box and worse producers in red box. There are shallow wells (pink, green and purple) producing at good rates with moderate gas; there are deep wells (blue) producing with high GOR. Consequently there is not a clear depth dependency with productivity.

formatted-caption.caption-text: Performance of wells drilled at different depths. Wells are colour coded by depth. Note best producers in green box and worse producers in red box. There are shallow wells (pink, green and purple) producing at good rates with moderate gas; there are deep wells (blue) producing with high GOR. Consequently there is not a clear depth dependency with productivity.

linkTarget.anchoringText: Analytical modeling has been backed up by additional dynamic simulation conducted using simple box models to address residual uncertainties associated with the floor well GOGD concept in a fractured reservoir (see Fig.13)

image-wrap.label: Figure 13
image-wrap.caption: Comparing the GOGD analytical forecasts with the simulated box model forecast. Blue: analytical forecast high case. Red: analytical forecast reference case. Green: box model simulation forecast using a deep floor well.

formatted-caption.caption-text: Comparing the GOGD analytical forecasts with the simulated box model forecast. Blue: analytical forecast high case. Red: analytical forecast reference case. Green: box model simulation forecast using a deep floor well.

image-wrap.label: Figure 14
image-wrap.caption: Left) Illustration of fracture concept highlighting Alpine-1 (NW-SE) and −2 (NE-SW) main fracture corridors. Right) Dual permeability simulation box model to represent a matrix block (blue) surrounded by fracture corridors (red).

formatted-caption.caption-text: Left) Illustration of fracture concept highlighting Alpine-1 (NW-SE) and −2 (NE-SW) main fracture corridors. Right) Dual permeability simulation box model to represent a matrix block (blue) surrounded by fracture corridors (red).

figure-specific-caption.caption-text: Illustration of fracture concept highlighting Alpine-1 (NW-SE) and −2 (NE-SW) main fracture corridors
Dual permeability simulation box model to represent a matrix block (blue) surrounded by fracture corridors (red)

linkTarget.anchoringText: Pseudo-wells are used to mimic the continuous gas fluxes taking place across the reservoir that result in gas-filled fracture corridors. A pair of gas injector and oil producer wells is located updip and downdip fracture corridor respectively (see Fig.15). The injector is completed in the top layer (z=1), the producer is completed in the bottom layer (z=10).

image-wrap.label: Figure 15
image-wrap.caption: Schematic of the box model dimensions and well configurations, including position of pseudo wells used for boundary conditioning.

formatted-caption.caption-text: Schematic of the box model dimensions and well configurations, including position of pseudo wells used for boundary conditioning.

linkTarget.anchoringText: Upon volumetric initialization of the box model, dummy wells (producers) in the fracture corridors are activated to reduce the average reservoir pressure to current operating pressure. Once the operating pressure is reached, the dummy producers in the fracture corridors are closed in, the development well in the matrix block is activated, and the injectors in the fracture corridors start injecting gas through a monitor to maintain an average constant pressure of 30 bar (see fig.16). The development well(s) produce against a gas constraint / GOR level that is considered to be the maximum allowable operating level. Based on simulation work a floor well can produce comfortably for about 10 years against this gas constraint (see fig. 17).

image-wrap.label: Figure 16
image-wrap.caption: Evolution of gas saturations (green) in the fracture network over time as the box model pressure is reduced

formatted-caption.caption-text: Evolution of gas saturations (green) in the fracture network over time as the box model pressure is reduced

linkTarget.anchoringText: Upon volumetric initialization of the box model, dummy wells (producers) in the fracture corridors are activated to reduce the average reservoir pressure to current operating pressure. Once the operating pressure is reached, the dummy producers in the fracture corridors are closed in, the development well in the matrix block is activated, and the injectors in the fracture corridors start injecting gas through a monitor to maintain an average constant pressure of 30 bar (see fig.16). The development well(s) produce against a gas constraint / GOR level that is considered to be the maximum allowable operating level. Based on simulation work a floor well can produce comfortably for about 10 years against this gas constraint (see fig. 17).

image-wrap.label: Figure 17
image-wrap.caption: Illustration of saturations in the matrix and in the fractures around a floor development well that is placed at the bottom of the matrix block, mid-way in the structure. Gas saturations are in green, oil saturations are in red. Left): map view. Right: cross sectional view.

formatted-caption.caption-text: Illustration of saturations in the matrix and in the fractures around a floor development well that is placed at the bottom of the matrix block, mid-way in the structure. Gas saturations are in green, oil saturations are in red. Left): map view. Right: cross sectional view.

linkTarget.anchoringText: The reference model was used to assess the impact of subsurface parameters, as illustrated in Table 1 and Fig. 18. In addition, sensitivities to block size, well length and multiwall placement were also simulated with the reference subsurface parameters.

image-wrap.label: Figure 18
image-wrap.caption: Tornado plot highlighting impact on recoverable volume for the low and high case ranges of the various subsurface parameters relative to the base case scenario.

formatted-caption.caption-text: Tornado plot highlighting impact on recoverable volume for the low and high case ranges of the various subsurface parameters relative to the base case scenario.

linkTarget.anchoringText: The key subsurface uncertainties influencing oil recovery in the simulation box model are the matrix permeability, the background fracture properties (permeability and spacing) and the gas oil capillary pressure (see Fig.18); the volumes associated to varying block size, depending on the fault density for different sectors of the field is important for the success of the individual wells (See Fig. 19).

image-wrap.label: Figure 19
image-wrap.caption: Block size and well length sensitivities. Left: cumulative oil production after 10 years (MMm3). Right: annualized oil production rates (m3/d). The legend explains the scenarios: box size / well length.

formatted-caption.caption-text: Block size and well length sensitivities. Left: cumulative oil production after 10 years (MMm3). Right: annualized oil production rates (m3/d). The legend explains the scenarios: box size / well length.

linkTarget.anchoringText: When two floor development wells are active at the same time, the simulation results show indeed that theoretical incremental recovery from the matrix block with these two wells is minor when compared to a single well development (see Fig.20). In practical terms, the strategy to pair wells to ensure drainage of potential subseismic blocks and to shelter deeper wells from gas should be further investigated. It is recommended to place the GOGD floor development well as downdip as possible in the structure to benefit from the structure dip and maximize oil recovery from the matrix block. In pragmatic terms that might be difficult to achieve for the smaller grid blocks.

image-wrap.label: Figure 20
image-wrap.caption: Well placement sensitivities. Left: recovery factor for the well positioned mid-way (green), the well positioned deep (pink), and both wells together (orange). Right: oil production rates (red) and GOR (green) for the well positioned mid-way (solid line) and the well positioned deep (dotted line).

formatted-caption.caption-text: Well placement sensitivities. Left: recovery factor for the well positioned mid-way (green), the well positioned deep (pink), and both wells together (orange). Right: oil production rates (red) and GOR (green) for the well positioned mid-way (solid line) and the well positioned deep (dotted line).

figure-specific-caption.caption-text: recovery factor for the well positioned mid-way (green), the well positioned deep (pink), and both wells together (orange)
oil production rates (red) and GOR (green) for the well positioned mid-way (solid line) and the well positioned deep (dotted line)

linkTarget.anchoringText: The risks associated with the wells are illustrated in the figure 21 below and described as follows:
